title: 113_hr1715
content: The Act titled "Expedited Consideration of Cuts, Consolidations, and Savings Act of 2013" allows for expedited consideration of cuts, consolidations, and savings prepared by the Office of Management and Budget. The Act allows the President to propose implementing recommendations from the Office of Management and Budget's Cuts, Consolidations, and Savings report. The President can transmit a special message to Congress within 120 days of the report's publication, along with a draft bill or joint resolution. Procedures for expedited consideration are outlined. The Act allows the President to propose implementing recommendations from the Office of Management and Budget's report. Within 120 days, the President can transmit a special message to Congress with a draft bill or joint resolution for expedited consideration. If not introduced by the majority or minority leader, any Member of the House can introduce the bill, which will be referred to the relevant committee without substantive revision. The bill or joint resolution must be reported within seven days of receiving a special message, or the committee will be discharged. A vote on final passage must occur within 10 days of introduction, and if passed, the Clerk of the House of Representatives will proceed. Upon agreement, the bill or joint resolution is engrossed, certified, and transmitted to the other House of Congress on the same day. It is then referred to the relevant committee for reporting within seven days without substantive revision. The resolution must be reported within seven days of receiving the bill or joint resolution. If a committee fails to report within this period, they are automatically discharged from consideration. A vote on final passage must be taken within 10 days of the bill being transmitted to the House. If agreed upon, the bill is sent to the other House on the same day for further review. The engrossed bill or joint resolution must be returned to the House of Representatives or the Senate by the Secretary of the House or the Secretary of the Senate. Motion to proceed to consideration of a bill or joint resolution is highly privileged in the House of Representatives and not debatable. Debate on a bill or joint resolution under this section in the House of Representatives is limited to 4 hours. Consideration of a bill or joint resolution under this section shall be governed by the Rules of the House of Representatives, with appeals from decisions of the Chair decided without debate. The Senate motion to proceed to consider a bill or joint resolution under this section is privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill or resolution, along with any debatable motions or appeals, is limited to 10 hours. Debates on motions or appeals are limited to 1 hour. The Senate motion to proceed to consider a bill or joint resolution under this section is privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill or resolution, along with any debatable motions or appeals, is limited to 10 hours. Amendments to a bill or joint resolution considered under this section are prohibited. The resolution considered under this section can be brought up in either the House of Representatives or the Senate. No motion to suspend this subsection is allowed, and unanimous consent cannot suspend it either. Definitions for continuity of a session are provided, stating that a session is only broken by adjournment sine die, and days when the House is adjourned for more than 3 days are excluded from the calculation of any period. Amendments to bills or joint resolutions under this section are not allowed. Amendments are made to sections 1013 and 1018 of the Act, with corresponding changes to sections 1011 and 1015. Amendments are made to sections 1013 and 1018 of the Act, including changes to sections 1011 and 1015. Subsection (e)(2) is modified by inserting new subparagraphs and redesignating existing ones. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act. Amendments are made to sections 1013 and 1018 of the Act, including changes to sections 1011 and 1015. Subsection (e)(2) is modified by inserting new subparagraphs and redesignating existing ones. Clerical amendments are made to the table of sections for subpart B of title X of the Act. Additionally, items relating to sections 1013 through 1017 are redesignated as items relating to sections 1014 through 1018, with a new item inserted after section 1012. SEC. 1013 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 allows for expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions. This authority will terminate in 2018 when Congress adjourns sine die.
